Basic Information
History source: Patient.
History limitation: None.
Additional information: Chief Complaint from Nursing Triage Note : Chief Complaint
2022-08-31 5:12 EDT Chief Complaint L groin heart cath 2 days ago. Pt reports increase redness/swelling to post-op site .

History of Present Illness
The patient presents with left groin pain. 52-year old peripheral artery disease, coronary disease status post admission this month for an endovascular tear of the infrarenal aortic aneurysm with increasing left groin pain. The patient reports he left the hospital yesterday with a hematoma. He states it has gotten larger. He is having increasing pain. Apparently he has Courtney yet filled his prescription for narcotic pain medication. He endorses constipation but denies abdominal discomfort. He is Courtney anticoagulated at home. The patient denies any back pain..

Review of Systems
Constitutional symptoms: No fever, no chills.
Skin symptoms: No rash,
ENMT symptoms: No sore throat,
Respiratory symptoms: No shortness of breath, no cough.
Cardiovascular symptoms: No chest pain, no peripheral edema.
Gastrointestinal symptoms: left groin pain, no abdominal pain, no vomiting.
Genitourinary symptoms: No dysuria,
Musculoskeletal symptoms: No back pain, no Muscle pain.
Neurologic symptoms: No headache, no dizziness.
Endocrine symptoms: No hyperglycemia,
Hematologic/Lymphatic symptoms: Bleeding tendency negative, bruising tendency negative.

Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation, No focal neurological deficit observed.
Psychiatric: Cooperative.

Medical Decision Making

Documents reviewed: The patient was in-house the 29th through 30th for an endovascular repair of infrarenal aortic aneurysm. In June the patient underwent TCAR.

item.paragraph: (US Pseudoaneurysm Scan) Reason For Exam: hematoma, r/o pseudo

paragraph.content:
INDICATION: Pain and swelling/hematoma. Evaluate for pseudoaneurysm. Heart
catheterization 2 days ago. Abdominal aorta repair 2022-08-29. Left
endarterectomy 2022-06-06. Carotid stent 6/18/221. Heart stent x2; 2021-10-01.
Coronary artery bypass graft x4. Bypass graft.
TECHNIQUE: Ultrasound of the Left Groin.
COMPARISON: BLE venous US 2022-06-08.
FINDINGS:
There are no masses or collections identified within the area of concern within the
left groin. There are no focal fluid collections identified. There are no
sonographic abnormalities detected. There are no findings to suggest
pseudoaneurysm.
IMPRESSION:
No sonographic evidence of pseudoaneurysm.
Signed by James C Larsen III, MD

***** Final *****
Dictated by: LARSEN, JAMES, MD-RAD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-08-31 7:48 am
Interpreted and electronically signed by: LARSEN, JAMES, MD-RAD
Signed DT/TM: 2022-08-31 8:03 am

Former smoker; Month Tobacco Last Used quit 7 weeks ago (mid 2022-04-17);

text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Hematoma
A hematoma is a collection of blood under the skin, in an organ, in a body space, in a joint space, or in other tissue. The blood can thicken (clot) to form a lump that you can see and feel. The lump is often firm and may become sore and tender. Most hematomas get better in a few days to weeks. However, some hematomas may be serious and require medical care. Hematomas can range from very small to very large.
What are the causes?
This condition is caused by:
• A blunt or penetrating injury.
• A leakage from a blood vessel under the skin.
• Some medical procedures, including surgeries, such as oral surgery, face lifts, and surgeries on the joints.
• Some medical conditions that cause bleeding or bruising. There may be multiple hematomas that appear in different areas of the body.
What increases the risk?
You are more likely to develop this condition if:
• You are an older adult.
• You use blood thinners.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition depend on where the hematoma is located.
Common symptoms of a hematoma that is under the skin include:
• A firm lump on the body.
• Pain and tenderness in the area.
• Bruising. Blue, dark blue, purple-red, or yellowish skin (discoloration) may appear at the site of the hematoma if the hematoma is close to the surface of the skin.
Common symptoms of a hematoma that is deep in the tissues or body spaces may be less obvious. They include:
• A collection of blood in the stomach (intra-abdominal hematoma). This may cause pain in the abdomen, weakness, fainting, and shortness of breath.
• A collection of blood in the head (intracranial hematoma). This may cause a headache or symptoms such as weakness, trouble speaking or understanding, or a change in consciousness.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition is diagnosed based on:
• Your medical history.
• A physical exam.
• Imaging tests, such as an ultrasound or CT scan. These may be needed if your health care provider suspects a hematoma in deeper tissues or body spaces.
• Blood tests. These may be needed if your health care provider believes that the hematoma is caused by a medical condition.
How is this treated?
Treatment for this condition depends on the cause, size, and location of the hematoma. Treatment may include:
• Doing nothing. The majority of hematomas do Courtney need treatment as many of them go away on their own over time.
• Surgery or close monitoring. This may be needed for large hematomas or hematomas that affect vital organs.
• Medicines. Medicines may be given if there is an underlying medical cause for the hematoma.
Follow these instructions at home:
Managing pain, stiffness, and swelling
• If directed, put ice on the affected area.
◦ Put ice in a plastic bag.
◦ Place a towel between your skin and the bag.
◦ Leave the ice on for 20 minutes, 2–3 times a day for the first couple of days.
• If directed, apply heat to the affected area after applying ice for a couple of days. Use the heat source that your health care provider recommends, such as a moist heat pack or a heating pad.
◦ Place a towel between your skin and the heat source.
◦ Leave the heat on for 20–30 minutes.
◦ Remove the heat if your skin turns bright red. This is especially important if you are unable to feel pain, heat, or cold. You may have a greater risk of getting burned.
• Raise (elevate) the affected area above the level of your heart while you are sitting or lying down.
• If told, wrap the affected area with an elastic bandage. The bandage applies pressure (compression) to the area, which may help to reduce swelling and promote healing. Do Courtney wrap the bandage too tightly around the affected area.
• If your hematoma is on a leg or foot (lower extremity) and is painful, your health care provider may recommend crutches. Use them as told by your health care provider.
General instructions
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have a fever.
• The swelling or discoloration gets worse.
• You develop more hematomas.
Get help right away if:
• Your pain is worse or your pain is Courtney controlled with medicine.
• Your skin over the hematoma breaks or starts bleeding.
• Your hematoma is in your chest or abdomen and you have weakness, shortness of breath, or a change in consciousness.
• You have a hematoma on your scalp that is caused by a fall or injury, and you also have:
◦ A headache that gets worse.
◦ Trouble speaking or understanding speech.
◦ Weakness.
◦ Change in alertness or consciousness.
Summary
• A hematoma is a collection of blood under the skin, in an organ, in a body space, in a joint space, or in other tissue.
• This condition usually does Courtney need treatment because many hematomas go away on their own over time.
• Large hematomas, or those that may affect vital organs, may need surgical drainage or monitoring. If the hematoma is caused by a medical condition, medicines may be prescribed.
• Get help right away if your hematoma breaks or starts to bleed, you have shortness of breath, or you have a headache or trouble speaking after a fall.
This information is Courtney intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2021-03-13 Document Reviewed: 2020-03-23
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.
